Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2013 08:27AM MsJAR wrote: Rayna, yes, i do have depression, too.  Our surgeries were almost identical!  Nov 19,  bmx. Thought my right side was simply prophylactic, but pathology showed DCIs and LCIS in that side.  The left side was ILC with 1/6 lymph  nodes involvement. I chose not to do TEs,  but when Iooked into the mirror for the first time, I was horrified!  So I'm going to reserve the right to change my mind later.  My oncologist is allowing me to wait until the holidays are over to start chemo.  I will be taking ACT so it won't be fun.  My husband still works, so I'm alone a LOT of the time.  I HATE to have to ask for help from my kids who all work and have lives of their own.  So sometimes I just sit here and feel sorry for myself. Thank goodness for this forum!

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2013 03:06PM MsJAR wrote: Gotta share this story about my sweet granddaughter on Christmas.  Gracy, who is 8, asked for a piece of paper and a pencil. She sat working diligently on a drawing of herself and my other three grandchildren, my two cats, and myself.  She carefully labeled each one of us. When she was finished, she proudly presented it to me, explaining that she had drawn  me with long hair because that's how it used to be before i got sick.  Then she said she drew it for me so that when I died she would put it in my casket so that I would always remember them all.  It was so sweet and kind of funny, but i lost it and started crying. Didn't want to put a damper on the festivities so i quickly got control, but tears kept leaking throughout the day as i watched my grand babies wondering if i would see them grow up or would even be here next year.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2013 08:05PM MsJAR wrote: Scribblin, I'm one week behind you on surgery, mine was 19th.  Iam hoping to get my drains out tomorrow. I had been wearing the hateful old ace bandage continually except to wash and change my bandages, 24 /7. Last weekend i felt like I just had to have a breather from it.  By Monday morning, i could tell  there was swelling under my armpits.  As much as i hated to, i wrapped up in the ace again, and the swelling went back down.. there are some good videos on YouTube explaining lymph drainage and it seems to help some when i try that.  Please don't push yourself too much. Take care of you.

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2014 11:52AM MsJAR wrote: Dixie, I am right there with you.  I can hardly think of anything else.  Do you know what your regimen will be and how many sessions?  I'm taking ACT for 6 sessions.  If you are like me,  you have researched and read everything you can about it already.  Seems like it helps to be forewarned. After our first session we will know more what to expect each time. If you're having trouble sleeping or with anxiety, call your regular doctor and ask about something to help.  You have every right to feel nervous about it, but everyone wants to make it easier for you.  You will need your strength for recovering. Don't waste it now in anticipating.   Hugs, Dixie, and imagine me sitting there with you on C-day.

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2014 11:36AM MsJAR wrote: Hello, January sisters.  My treatments start on the 8th.  I will have ACT every three weeks for six sessions.  Neulasta on day after each treatment.  I've read that neulasta causes a good deal of bone pain and that Claritin helps with that. Also read that it is a good idea to use lidocaine cream (EMLA) on the port access spot an hour or two before tx to numb the skin. Put a glob right on the port and then cover it with a square of plastic wrap.  I'm all for anything that makes this journey easier.

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2013 12:11PM MsJAR wrote: Scalcott, when the surgeon does the lumpectomy, he will be able to tell you much more.  An experienced surgeon will have a good idea from the looks of the tissue whether you should be concerned. Choose one that you trust & respect.  If the pathology report comes back with good news, the lumpectomy might be all the surgery she needs...maybe with chemo and/or radiation to follow.  If the tumor is large or aggressive, further surgery may be needed, followed by the appropriate treatment. Try not to agonize until you find out, spend your energy staying positive and encouraging all you can.  We are here to help you if we can.  Big hugs! JoAnn
